snippet: The aid organization also raised the death toll in Saturday’s airstrike, saying that three more patients had died, raising the total fatalities to 22 — 10 patients and 12 staff members.
abstract: Doctors Without Borders announces it is leaving northern Afghanistan city of Kunduz after its hospital there suffers from catastrophic airstrike that leaves 22 people, including 12 staff members, dead; organization's hospital was only free trauma care hospital in country's northern region; hospital continued to operate even after Taliban took over city; both Pentagon and Afghan government have announced intentions to investigate the airstrike, which may have involved American military operations.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Helene Cooper from Madrid; Eric Schmitt and Matthew Rosenberg from Washington; Jawad Sukhanyar and Ahmad Shakib from Kabul; and an employee of The New York Times from Baghlan Province, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: The aid organization also raised the death toll in Saturday’s airstrike, saying that three more patients had died, raising the total fatalities to 22 — 10 patients and 12 staff members.

headline.main: Doctors Without Borders Says It Is Leaving Kunduz After Strike on Hospital
headline.print_headline: Doctors Without Borders Exits Afghan City as Fight Worsens

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
